Award.AwardTitle: IPG: Collaborative Research: Research on East African Catarrhine and Hominoid Evolution

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
New evidence from early fossil humans suggests that, in some respects, these hominins more closely resembled the earliest fossil apes than any modern ape. While such findings substantially impact our understanding of early hominin adaptive morphology, their precise implications remain unclear because the original ecological conditions in which these features evolved is poorly documented. To address this problem, this project will answer the following three research questions: What are the regional patterns of environmental change and the site-specific habitats associated with the earliest fossil apes? How does the morphology of early apes relate to the environmental contexts in which they lived? How do early ape adaptations inform our understanding of later ape and human evolution? These questions will be answered by establishing a multi-disciplinary, multi-national collaboration to initiate new paleontological field research at all of the early fossil ape localities in East Africa. For the first time, new fossil and data collection will be coordinated across nearly a dozen Kenyan sites near Kisingiri, Tinderet, West Turkana, and Buluk, and a similar number of Ugandan sites at Napak, Moroto, and Bukwa. In addition to surveys and excavation, a series of geological, ecological, and taphonomic analyses will be used to understand the age, environment, and setting of each locality. New fossils will be subjected to rigorous morphological analyses to determine their evolutionary and adaptive significance. Unlike previous studies, which have focused on individual localities, this regional approach to understanding ancient ecosystems will track environmental variations over the time and space of early ape evolution, making it possible to relate specific habitat types with primate adaptive morphology.

The origin and early diversification of the ape-human lineage represents a fundamental shift in primate body plans, and is therefore an integral resource for interpreting the later evolution of apes and humans. For decades, most researchers have studied human origins through the lens of modern ape and human characteristics, marginalizing a large and diverse body of evidence from their ancient ape predecessors. This project represents an important and substantive step toward fully integrating our knowledge of living and fossil apes and humans. Moreover, coordinating a project of this breadth - using the same methods and protocols across all of the relevant fossil sites - will allow data to be synthesized on a scale not previously possible, setting new benchmarks for conducting future field projects. This project will thus model a collaborative approach that will be more productive and beneficial to the discipline of paleoanthropology.

This project also generates substantial broader impacts. A critical component of the grant is the training of US and East Africa graduate and US undergraduate students in the discipline of paleoanthropology. The project also includes the National Museums of Kenya as a full collaborative scientific partner in the proposed research. A well-established partnership between University of Michigan, Makerere University and the National Museum (Uganda) will be fostered by this grant, helping to train staff and students in Uganda on field and analytical techniques. Finally, a digital database cataloging all the fossils and data collected from all of the localities will be made freely available after the conclusion of the project.

Institution.Name: University of Minnesota-Twin Cities
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to fully develop a regional geochronology, paleoecology, paleoenvironment, and biogeography of early ape fossil sites in eastern Africa. The core of this research was coordinated paleontological and geological fieldwork at 10 fossil catarrhine field sites, together This work was paired with a battery of geological, taphonomic, and paleoecological analyses to produce a highly resolved and geochronologically calibrated model of easter African paleoenvironments. We used these analyses to test hypotheses about the evolution of ape features that are critical and necessary to understand the adaptive context of later hominoid, and more importantly, hominin evolution.

The project sought and found answers to three fundamental research questions:

1. What are the regional patterns of paleoenvironmental change and the site-specific ecologies of early Miocene fossil sites in East Africa?

2. What are the relationships between derived catarrhine adaptations and their environmental contexts in the early Miocene?

3. How does the adaptive significance of early Miocene morphological complexes inform our understanding of hominoid evolution and the origin of the human lineage?

The integrated research provided critical insight into the adaptive significance of ape and human evolutionary morphology, but it also generated significant collaborations and intellectual infrastructure, modeling a new mode of paleoanthropological research.

The intellectual merits of this project were in adopting a uniquely regional perspective to understanding the origin and diversification of the ape and human clade. The battery of paleoecological and geochronological methods represented significant advances over most previous works, which report individual methods applied to individual sites. By coordinating a project of this breadth, using the same protocols, we were able to synthesize data on a scale not previously possible, and establish new benchmarks for conducting future field projects. The practice of individual research silos ? wherein ideas and evidence remain sequestered until published ? is antithetical to the basic notion of scientific exchange. We demonstrated through this project that a collaborative approach is not only possible, but ultimately much more productive and beneficial to paleoanthropology.

This project also achieved substantial broader impacts. This is one of the first projects in recent times to include the National Museums of Kenya as a full collaborative partner in the scientific research. Drs. Mbua and Manthi were directly involved in the oversight and advancement of this project. Likewise, this project specifically budgeted for graduate training for two eastern African students. In this manner, we brought the intellectual resources and perspectives of these colleagues to our collaborative institutions, while assisting their rise though the academic ranks. We also dedicated funds to rehabilitating the Songhor Prehistoric Site, which will ensure that this important locality remains a valuable paleontological resources for future scientists.


Last Modified: 07/05/2021
Modified by: Kieran P Mcnulty
